philosophers.name: Aristotle
philosophers.bio: A Greek polymath and student of Plato who laid the foundations for Western logic, science, and ethics through the concept of virtue.

philosophers.name: Immanuel Kant
philosophers.bio: A central Enlightenment thinker who argued that human reason creates morality and that duty is the highest standard of action.

philosophers.name: Friedrich Nietzsche
philosophers.bio: A cultural critic who challenged traditional morality and Christianity, emphasizing the 'will to power' and self-overcoming.

philosophers.name: Fyodor Dostoevsky
philosophers.bio: A novelist whose works explore the deepest depths of human psychology, faith, and the conflict between reason and the soul.

philosophers.name: Leo Tolstoy
philosophers.bio: A literary giant who later advocated for non-violent resistance, simple living, and a moral interpretation of Christianity.

philosophers.name: Confucius
philosophers.bio: A teacher and philosopher who emphasized social harmony, filial piety, and the moral responsibilities of rulers and subjects.
